South China University of Technology China Graphical abstract Low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is an efficient and promising technology to transform NOx into N2 from flue gases, which has broad application prospects. However, the vulnerability of low temperature DeNOx catalysts to poisoning by SO2 and H2O restricts their industrial application. Therefore, it is vitally important to develop new low temperature DeNOx catalysts that resist poisoning. This paper reviews the mechanisms of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts, the strategies for improving the resistance of low temperature SCR catalysts to SO2 & H2O poisoning, application of theoretical calculations in the development of SO2 & H2O resistant low temperature SCR catalysts as well as novel ideas for developing poisoning resistant low temperature SCR catalysts. Moreover, the studies dealing with the regeneration of low temperature DeNOx catalysts are also included. Based on the problems detailed in this review, the challenges and the emphasis for future research in this area are also proposed. We believe that this review will provide an excellent foundation and good guidance for the future design and the development of improved SO2 & H2O-tolerant low temperature DeNOx catalysts. Keywords Low temperature SCR DeNOx catalyst H2O and SO2 resistance Regeneration 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NOx) is one of the most serious air pollutants present in the atmosphere and it can produce a sequence of environmental issues, such as photochemical smog, acid rain, and ozone layer depletion and it also significantly contributes to the formation of atmospheric haze [1]. Emitted NOx also causes great harm to the ecology and human health, both of which have attracted increasing attention throughout the world. Fossil fuel combustion emission of NOx as a direct result of the energy expended over the last century in industrial production and residential life has been the primary source of NOx in the atmosphere [2]. Hence, removal of NOx from flue gases has become an increasingly urgent task as a means for improving ambient air quality [1,2]. Among the various available post-combustion technologies (selective catalytic reduction, catalytic decomposition, liquid absorption, plasma catalysis, etc.), selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with NH3 is currently the most popular approach for flue gases denitrification (DeNOx) from stationary sources (thermal power plants, industrial boilers, etc.), which is due to its maturity and high efficiency [3,4]. Today, the commercial DeNOx catalyst (V2O5-WO3/TiO2), with an operating range of 300–400 °C, is the key to the NH3-SCR technology and, as such, it has been extensively studied [4]. This operating temperature range results from the fact that the optimum reaction temperature of the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is about 350 °C. And the SCR unit must be located upstream from the particle remover or desulfurizer device to avoid reheating of the flue gas. However, this arrangement causes the catalyst to be more susceptible to deactivation from high concentrations of dust (e.g., K2O, CaO and As2O3) and SO2 [3,5]. In addition, V2O5-based catalysts are potential biological toxicants [6]. Consequently, when discarded, they are classified as a hazardous waste, so the ultimate disposal of deactivated catalysts can also be a major problem. From the perspective of efficiency, economy and boiler matching, the low temperature NH3-SCR technology can efficiently convert NOx into N2 in a temperature range of 120–200 °C, which has great economic benefit and broad application [7,8]. With the increasingly stringent emission limits of NOx and the increasing enforcement of environmental protection law in China, medium temperature SCR DeNOx technology that has been adopted in the power industry could not fully meet the actual needs [9]. Low temperature SCR technology offers great potential for application in the power industry, but also is urgently needed in other industries (coking, cement, waste incineration, acid pickling, iron and steel, etc.) [10]. The flue gas temperature from these other industries is primarily below 300 °C. The components in the flue gasses of these industries (mainly SO2, H2O and dust) vary greatly and the working conditions are unstable. For example, the flue gas from waste incineration is usually at low temperature, with high humidity (> 20%) and dioxins are present in the flue gas [11]. Therefore, the medium temperature SCR technology normally employed in thermal power plants is not fully suitable for non-electric industries so that the problem of SO2 & H2O poisoning of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst persists. Consequently, low temperature SCR technology is still in the investigational stages and has been mainly applied in the laboratory or on a small scale, and the core problem of the technology remains the development of a low temperature SCR DeNOx catalyst that can be fielded for use in industry. In the field of industrial application of the low temperature SCR technology, a research team led by Professor He of Beijing University of Chemical Technology has modified the traditional V-W-Ti system to make it useful in low temperature flue gas conditions by developing a series of methods. These have included improving the catalyst formulation and carrier [12,13]. In 2015, this group began to apply the improved catalyst for use in the Baosteel Zhanjiang coke oven DeNOx project [13]. However, at present, a suitable non-vanadium, low temperature SCR DeNOx catalyst with high efficiency, strong anti-poisoning properties and environmental friendliness is still in the research and development stage, and much work remains to take it from the laboratory scale to industrial application. Currently, the main obstacle to the industrialization of this low temperature technology is the SO2 & H2O poisoning of the low temperature DeNOx catalysts [14–16]. Consequently, the key to the industrial application of the low temperature NH3-SCR technology is to develop an environmental-friendly, efficient, stable and poisoning-resistant low temperature SCR catalyst. At present, transition metal oxides are the major active component in low temperature SCR catalysts. These include VOx [12,17], CeOx [16], CuOx [18], MnOx [19–22], FeOx [23,24], etc. These catalysts have been reportedly used in the form of supported catalysts, mixed oxide solid solutions and conventional metal oxides. Most of the reported low temperature SCR catalysts exhibit excellent low temperature SCR activity in flue gas containing no SO2 & H2O [16,19]. However, actual flue gas contains about 5–20% water vapor and 50–300 ppm SO2, and the current catalysts are vulnerable to poisoning and deactivation under these conditions [25,26]. Although many low temperature SCR catalysts can recover some of their catalytic activity following regeneration at high temperature, water washing or H2 reduction [27], frequent catalyst regeneration is not compatible with the continuous operation of an industrial plant. Therefore, improving the SO2 & H2O tolerance of low temperature SCR catalysts is the key to the practical application of this SCR technology. Over time, researchers have conducted a considerable quantity of work in this area from which many useful research findings have been gleaned [28–30]. To date, progress in the research on low temperature catalytic reduction of NOx using NH3 in China and abroad has been extensively detailed in the literature. A review by Liu et al. summarized the behavior of MnOx-based catalysts and focused on improving the activity of the catalysts and describing the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism at low temperature [19]. A review by Boningari et al. also provided a comprehensive overview of NH3-SCR chemistry for aspects of the reaction mechanism over Mn-based catalysts by employing isotopic labeled and in situ FT-IR analysis [9]. However, little effort has been expended reviewing the research on low temperature catalyst deactivation and the catalyst regeneration processes. A recent review by Zhang et al. also dealt with MnOx-based low temperature catalysts from the perspective of reaction mechanisms and the catalyst deactivation processes [15]. Although there are many review articles in the literature describing catalysts for low temperature DeNOx, there have been few reports that have focused on the problem of SO2 & H2O poisoning in low temperature SCR catalysts. This present review emphases the recent progress in the development of low temperature DeNOx catalysts that exhibit high tolerance to SO2 & H2O and also summarizes and discusses the mechanism of the SO2 & H2O poisoning of the low temperature SCR catalyst, the strategy of improving poisoning resistance of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst to SO2 & H2O, application of theoretical calculations in the development of SO2 & H2O resistant low temperature SCR catalysts, etc. We hope that this review will be used as a guide for the rational design and development of low temperature SCR catalysts for industrial use. 2 The SO2 & H2O poisoning mechanism of low temperature SCR catalysts Improving the SO2 & H2O resistance of low temperature DeNOx catalyst has become an increasingly urgent problem that requires a practical solution. In order to improve the SO2 & H2O resistance of these catalysts, it is necessary to study and understand the SO2 & H2O poisoning phenomenon of the low temperature DeNOx catalysts. Many studies have shown that the effects of SO2 and H2O on the SCR performance of these catalysts are not only closely related to the active components in the catalysts, but are also related to the microstructures of catalysts and the physicochemical properties of supports [5,31]. Kijlstra and coworkers conducted an investigation of the possible SO2 deactivation routes contributed to the deactivation of MnOx/Al2O3 catalysts at low temperature [31]. Their results showed that formation of a large quantity of MnSO4 on the surface of the catalyst was the primary cause of the sulfur poisoning of the catalyst. Pan et al. [25] also conducted a comprehensive study of the effect of the presence of SO2 on the low temperature SCR activity of MnOx/MWCNTs (multi-walled carbon nanotubes) catalysts. Through a series of chemical characterizations, the authors concluded that the sulfation of the active center sites in the catalyst led to the irreversible deactivation of the catalyst, which was the primary cause of deactivation. Their results also showed that the formation and deposition of ammonium sulfates and competitive adsorption between reactant molecules and toxicants on the catalyst surface also contributed to the deactivation of the catalyst [25]. Jiang et al. [32] prepared Fe-Mn/TiO2 catalysts using a sol-gel method and investigated the effect of SO2 on the low temperature DeNOx process using in situ DRIFTs (diffuse reflectance FTIR). These authors found that the SO2 was preferentially adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst over NO, and the SO2 formed a bidentate mononuclear sulfate (Fig. 1 ) [32]. This sulfate species can hinder the formation of the NO complex, but the authors found that SO2 had little effect on the adsorption of NH3. When SO2 is present in flue gas, the Langmuir-Hinshelwood reaction pathway for the low temperature SCR reaction is inhibited, which produces a decrease of catalyst activity. A research team led by Professor Bai from the National Chiao Tung University designed and prepared Fe-Mn/TiO2 catalysts that contained different species of sulfur compounds [33]. Through a series of characterization methods such as TG, NH3-TPD, etc., they found that the metal sulfates produced a more serious deactivation effect on the catalyst than of ammonium salts (Fig. 2 ). In other words, the sulfation of the active Mn atom was the main cause for the sulfur poisoning of the catalyst [33]. Hence, with respect to Mn-based low temperature SCR catalysts, the main reason for their sulfur deactivation is the sulfation of active Mn center atom [25,26,31]. However, formation of the ammonium sulfate and the competitive adsorption of SO2 & NO could also contribute to deactivation [5,19]. In this author’s opinion, deciphering the cause or mechanism of sulfur poisoning of Mn-based low temperature SCR catalysts is a step in the right direction, but this accomplishment is far from sufficient. Understanding the contribution of the various poisoning effects on the decline in the activity of low temperature SCR catalysts is also needed, which will play an important role in further improving Mn-based low temperature SCR catalysts. It is now generally accepted that the formation of a large amount of ammonium sulfates (ammonium bisulfate and ammonium sulfate) on the surface of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst containing V2O5 as the active component is the main reason for the deactivation of the catalyst [5,12,34]. These ammonium sulfates apparently clog the pore channels in the catalyst and occupy active sites, which leads to the deactivation of the V-based DeNOx catalyst. Recently, zeolite-based catalysts have attracted great attention due to their excellent properties such as excellent adsorption performance, suitable surface acidity, good shape selectivity and adaptability, as well as their capability to introduce transition metal elements in the structure [5,35–37]. In recent years, in the development of low temperature SCR catalysts, the SO2 tolerance of molecular sieve zeolite catalysts has received extensive attention by many workers [38,39]. SO2 poisoning of these types of catalysts over low temperature ranges can occur via varied mechanisms as a result of different SO2 concentrations in the flue gas, or by different feed forms of SO2, different active species, or various topological structures of zeolite carriers [5,39,40]. For instance, William Epling et al. [41] evaluated the effect of flue gas sulfur dioxide on SCR reaction performance, and the physical and chemical properties of the employed Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst. These authors’ results showed that the main reason for the decline in the low temperature SCR performance of the catalyst was the formation of ammonium sulfates at low temperature. The catalyst deactivation was also caused by contributions from the competitive adsorption between SO2 and NOx. Qu and co-workers [42] confirmed that the competitive adsorption between SO2 and NOx on the active sites of the Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts with a nanosheet morphology led to a significant decline in catalytic activity at relatively low temperatures. To sum up, among these catalysts including metal-oxide catalyst, supported catalyst or zeolite molecular sieve catalyst, the poisoning effect of SO2 on these low temperature DeNOx catalysts includes the following aspects: (1) SO2 reacts with active components, resulting in the sulfation of active center atoms and formation metal sulfates; (2) O2, SO2 and NH3 produce ammonium sulfate through a series of chemical reactions which deposits on the surface of the catalyst covering the active sites on the surface of the catalyst and blocking the pore channels; (3) NO and SO2 compete for active sites on the catalyst surface. Water vapor is the main component of actual flue gas and it also can produce catalyst deactivation. Water is present in the flue gas, but it is also a product of the NH3-SCR reaction. Consequently, even under dry conditions, the activity of the SCR catalysts may be adversely affected by the water vapor produced by the NH3-SCR reaction to some extent. It is well known that the SCR reaction begins with the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst [43]. The deactivation of the low temperature SCR catalysts by water vapor is primarily caused by the competitive adsorption of water vapor and NH3, which reduces the number of active sites on the catalyst [25,44]. In general, the effect of H2O to the low temperature DeNOx catalyst can be reversible [15,25]. A large volume of experimental data has shown that the activity of SCR catalyst can be gradually restored when the quantity of water vapor injected into a flue gas stream is decreased. However, the deactivation of the catalyst caused by the formation of additional surface hydroxyls (−OH) on the catalyst during the DeNOx reaction process was irreversible [19]. This was primarily due to the fact that the surface hydroxyl (−OH) groups formed by the decomposition of water vapor on the catalyst can only be removed at relatively high temperature (>250 °C) [19]. In fact, the flue gases of almost all industrial processes that require treatment contain water vapor. Many studies that have been conducted in the absence of water vapor do not reflect the reality of the application. However, from a fundamental point of view, these studies could help us to evaluate and improve the catalysts used in the NH3-SCR reaction. In addition, the deactivation of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst is more severe when the SO2 & H2O are simultaneously present, which is an indication that SO2 & H2O appear to exhibit a synergistic toxicity in the poisoning of the catalyst [25,45]. To date, some progress has been made in understanding the mechanism of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature DeNOx catalysts [25,31,45]. The causes of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts have been generally identified, but many unresolved issues remain in the development of low temperature DeNOx catalysts with high resistance to SO2 & H2O. The following aspects deserve further study. (1) Most of the studies on the mechanism of sulfur poisoning in low temperature SCR catalysts are based on ex situ methods, and there have been few systematically combined in situ and ex situ characterization methods employed to study the mechanism of catalyst poisoning under real conditions. (2) There have been few reports on the kinetics of the catalyst deactivation reaction at low temperature in flue gas containing SO2 & H2O, so this should be an active area of research. (3) The relationship between the SO2 oxidation of low temperature SCR catalyst and the sulfur tolerance of low temperature SCR as well as the related deactivation mechanism remains unclear, so this should be actively pursued. (4) The stability, kinetics and thermodynamics of the sulfate species in the DeNOx process using low temperature SCR catalysts in flue gases containing SO2 & H2O has not been reported, which makes this a desirable area of future work. The above-mentioned issues are important areas for future scientific research on the design and development of low temperature SCR catalysts with a strong resistance to poisoning. 3 Strategies to reduce SO2 poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts 3.1 Catalyst modification 3.1.1 Mn based DeNOx catalyst Catalysts that contain a single MnOx as the active component exhibit excellent low temperature SCR activity in the absence of SO2. For example, Wang et al. [20] and Wu et al. [46] prepared supported manganese oxide-based catalysts that produced over 90% NO conversion at low temperature. However, SO2 exerted a serious poisoning effect on the SCR reaction performance of the Mn-based catalysts, where the NO conversion rate was reported to rapidly decrease to less than 50% upon introduction of 100 ppm of SO2 under a GHSV of 30,000 h−1 [47,48]. Unlike the V-based catalysts, the main source for the deactivation of the Mn-based catalysts produced by SO2 was the sulfation of the active Mn atom, which often caused rapid catalyst deactivation and the deactivated Mn-based catalyst was often difficult to regenerate [25,47,48]. Therefore, many researchers have tried to improve the SO2 resistance performance of the Mn-based catalysts by doping the catalyst with other metal elements. Generally speaking, the SCR activity and SO2 resistance of the catalyst can be further improved by doping it with additional rare earth elements (Ce [48–50], Pr [39,51], Sm [52,53], Eu [54–56], Gd [57], Ho [58,59], etc.) and other transition metals (Fe [60–63], Co [64–66], Cr [67], Ni [64,68], W [69], Sn [70], etc.). Additive doping may alleviate the poisoning of MnOx which primarily results from the preferential reaction of the catalyst with SO2 to form sulfates or by reducing the thermal stability of ammonium sulfate. CeO2 is an important rare earth metal oxide that exhibits an excellent oxygen storage/release capability and strong oxidation-reduction performance, but it also exhibits an increase NH3 adsorption after sulfation [71–73]. More importantly, Ce-modified catalysts may reduce the sulfation of Mn active sites and the formation of ammonium sulfate [74,75]. Therefore, the addition of Ce to the Mn-based catalysts can promote the activity and sulfur resistance of the catalyst [76]. Jin et al. [48,77,78] prepared a CeO2 modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst by using sol-gel method and used it to a low temperature NH3-SCR reaction in flue gas containing SO2. It was found that the sulfur resistance of Ce-modified Mn/TiO2 catalyst was greatly improved, and the NO conversion rate of the modified catalyst was still above 60% after 10 h of reaction in a flue gas containing 100 ppm SO2 (GHSV = 40,000 h−1). The main reason for the improved SO2-tolerant performance of the Ce-doped catalysts was that surface sulfates were preferentially formed on the Ce dopants in the presence of SO2 during the SCR reaction, so less sulfation of the main active phase (MnOx) occurred and a portion of the Lewis acid sites on MnOx were preserved to fulfill the low temperature SCR reaction cycle [78]. Moreover, Ce doping decreases the stability of the sulfate on the catalyst surface, which increases its rate of decomposition, thereby reducing the amount of sulfate on the catalyst surface [78]. The effect of the modification of the SCR catalyst using other metal elements to improve the anti-poisoning properties of the Mn-Ce SCR catalysts has also been studied using elements such as Nb [79], Fe [80,81], Co [64,82], Sn [26], Ho [83] and W [84–86]. Of these doping elements, is was found that the resistance to SO2 can be greatly enhanced by adding Sn, Co or W to the Mn-Ce SCR catalysts. It was also reported that when the reaction temperature is increased from 150 to 200 °C, the SO2 resistance of these catalysts was also enhanced [82]. This was believed to be mainly due to the fact that at lower temperatures the ammonium sulphate accumulated more easily on the surface of the catalyst. Chang et al. [26,87] found that Sn doping can improve the low temperature SCR activity and SO2 resistance of the Mn(0.4)-Ce(0.5) catalysts. Almost no apparent decline in NO conversion was found for the Sn(0.1)-Mn(0.4)-Ce(0.5) catalyst in the presence of 100 ppm SO2 over 15 h at 250 °C (GHSV = 35,000 h−1) and this result suggested that the catalyst had excellent sulfur tolerance. Gao et al. [64] prepared Co or Ni doped-MnOx-CeO2 catalysts by a co-precipitation method, which exhibited high SCR performance in the presence of 150 ppm SO2 at 170 °C for over 240 min (GHSV = 48,000 h−1). Gao et al. also proposed a theory to explain how the SO2 tolerant performance of the Co or Ni doped-MnOx-CeO2 catalysts could be improved [64]. And further research led these authors to conclude that the NOx adsorbed on modified catalyst tend to form bidentate nitrate without the influence of SO2, which is then transformed into a monodentate nitrate species, which generates new Brønsted acid sites and then NH4 +. This was verified using in situ DRIFTS analysis and the related mechanisms for this process are shown in Fig. 3 . Also, the formation of ammonium sulfate and metal sulfate species on the catalysts was inhibited by Ni or Co doping. In addition, Shen and co-workers [88] determined that Fe and Co doped Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts exhibited a strong resistance to SO2 at 200 °C, which was attributed to the Fe and Co that effectively decreased the SO2 adsorption on the doped catalysts. Previous studies by our group demonstrated that highly dispersed MnOx/SAPO-34 catalysts exhibited high SCR reaction performance at low temperature. In addition, using the ionic polarization theory, praseodymium was screened as an effective additive to resist catalyst poisoning by SO2. The results showed that the doping of Pr could indeed improve the sulfur resistance of catalyst [39]. The model for the effect of Pr doping on the SO2-resistance of the catalysts is shown in Fig. 4 . Meng et al. [52] developed a SmOx modified MnOx catalyst that exhibited high SO2 resistant in the SCR reaction at 100 °C. After doping with Sm, there was very little restraint to the NOx conversion of the catalyst in the presence of 50 ppm SO2 at 100 °C and the conversion of NOx was reduced to 91% in the presence of 2% H2O and 100 ppm SO2 over 15 h under a GHSV of 48,600 h−1 (Fig. 5 ). They suggested that a possible reason for the excellent SO2 durability of the catalyst was the introduction of Sm that induced the deposition of bulk sulfate on Sm2O3, thereby inhibiting the SO2 poisoning of the active MnOx site. Recently, Dong and co-workers [89] reported the high sulfur tolerance of SmOx-ZrOx-MnOx catalysts that were prepared by reverse co-precipitation method [89]. In the presence of SO2 & H2O at 200 °C for over 10 h, the NO conversion rate for the SmOx-ZrOx-MnOx catalysts remained above 85% under a GHSV of 30,000 h−1. This result further demonstrated that introduction of Sm into the MnOx could reduce the rate of formation of the sulfate species and decrease the SO2 oxidation efficiency, thereby improving the ability of SO2-tolerant of the catalyst (Fig. 6 ). The authors also claimed that the catalyst had a very suitable oxidation rate of SO2, and the SO2 tolerance of the catalyst was the optimum under these conditions. In addition, the resistance for SO2 was also found to increase by adding Eu [54] and Gd [57] to Mn-based low temperature SCR catalysts. Most of the studies that have been conducted in the development of Fe-doped Mn based catalysts for low temperature DeNOx process have also reported a significant enhancement in the anti-SO2 poisoning performance of the Mn-based catalyst [61,90]. Qi et al. [91] was the first to report that the rate of sulfate compound formation on the Mn-based catalyst was reduced by Fe doping. Subsequently, Chen et al. [62] developed FeMnOx catalysts by using a citric acid method, which showed that addition of the Fe element promoted SO2 resistance in the catalysts. However, the SCR activity of these catalysts was still somewhat suppressed in the presence of SO2. The NOx conversion decreased slowly, and about 8% of its activity was lost over 4 h when 100 ppm SO2 was added to the 120 °C reaction gas stream under a GHSV of 30,000 h−1. The main reason for this strong sulfur-poisoning resistance was that the catalyst had two active centers (MnOx and Fe3Mn3O8), and the presence of the Fe3Mn3O8 phase somewhat reduced the poisoning of MnOx phase [62]. The CrMn2O4 spinel catalyst is another example of how specific crystalline phases in catalysts can play a key role in its resistance to sulfur poisoning [92]. The CrMn2O4 spinel catalyst reported by Gao et al. [92] exhibited good anti-poisoning performance. It was theorized that the presence of a specific CrMn2O4 phase and the resulting formation of Cr(III) sulfate in the presence of SO2 played the key roles in protecting the active Mn sites from sulfating, which produced good SO2-tolerance of the catalyst. The mechanisms of the SO2 tolerance in the NH3-SCR on the CrMn2O4 spinel catalyst are presented in Fig. 7 . In regard to the Mn-based low temperature SCR catalysts, several specific crystalline phases (Fe3Mn3O8 or CrMn2O4 phase) exist in this catalyst which provides it with some anti-poisoning properties. Although researchers have reported a schematic diagram for the initial mechanisms of the SO2 tolerance of the NH3-SCR catalysts, the intrinsic mechanism and key factors of the anti-poisoning properties of the catalysts still require further study. Zhu et al. [58] prepared Ho doped Fe-Mn/TiO2 catalysts using an impregnation method. The DeNOx efficiency of the catalysts exceeded 80% in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 and 15% H2O under a GHSV of 20,000 h−1. Unfortunately, in this reported study no further explanation was provided for the strong anti-SO2 sulfur-poisoning ability of the Ho-Fe-Mn/TiO2 catalyst. 3.1.2 V based DeNOx catalyst The successful application of traditional commercial vanadium-titanium catalysts in the field of SCR has prompted researchers to improve on the low temperature DeNOx activity as well as anti-poisoning performance of these catalysts to meet the requirements of low temperature NH3-SCR [3,93–95]. Zhu et al. [96] prepared a V2O5/AC catalyst and found that the 80% NO conversion could be attained at 250 °C (WHSV = 90,000 mLg−1 h−1). The authors claimed that the reactivity of NH4HSO4 with NO, rather than its decomposition, was associated with the behavior of the catalysts in the SCR reaction in the presence of SO2. They reported that the NO conversion rate increased to more than 90% and NO conversion increased rather than decreased when SO2 was introduced into the flue gas. Bai et al. [97,98] studied the effect of SO2 on the activity of a V2O5/CNTs catalyst at different temperatures, and found that SO2 actually promoted the NH3-SCR reaction when the temperature was higher than 200 °C, but SO2 inhibited the SCR reaction when the temperature was lower than 200 °C. In addition, compared to V2O5/TiO2, the CNTs appeared to promote the decomposition of the NH4HSO4 on the surface of V2O5/CNTs and NH4HSO4 on the surface of V2O5/CNTs was found to react with NO, which was not the case with V2O5/TiO2 [98]. Although at low temperature the SCR performance of the catalyst containing V2O5 as the active component is not as good as the catalyst containing MnOx as the active component, the sulfur poisoning resistance of the V2O5 based catalyst is relatively better than the Mn-based catalyst. In order to develop low temperature V-based DeNOx catalyst with a strong anti-poisoning capability, researchers have modified the catalyst by doping it with various elements to improve the low temperature SCR performance and anti-sulfur poisoning capability of the catalyst. These elements include Ce [12,34,99–101], Fe [102], Cu [103], Nb [104], Sb [105,106], Mo [107], etc. Numerous studies have been reported to investigate Ce-doped catalysts for the low temperature NH3-SCR reaction. According to literature, doping with Ce can significantly enhance the low temperature performance of a V-based catalyst, but it can also improve SO2 poisoning resistance of the catalyst. Weng and co-workers [34] reported that the SO2 resistance of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 was significantly enhanced by Ce doping, and at a GHSV of 150,000 h−1 the NOx conversion rate decreased by only 10% in a flue gas containing 60 ppm SO2 at 190 °C. The reason for the slight decrease in activity of the catalyst in the flue gas containing SO2 was the deposition of NH4HSO4. However, Ce-doped catalysts can reduce the formation of sulfates on the surface [34]. Ha et al. [105] used quantitative calculations to select and then prepare a SbOx-V2O5/TiO2 catalyst. When SO2 was introduced into the flue gas at a reaction temperature of 240 °C, the NO conversion of catalyst was more than 90% at a GHSV of 60,000 h−1. Based on Ha's research, Lee et al. [100] prepared Ce modified SbOx-V2O5/TiO2 catalysts, which exhibited a high tolerance to SO2. The DeNOx efficiency of the catalysts exceeded 80% with a flue gas containing 800 ppm SO2 and 6% H2O over 38 h (GHSV = 60,000 h−1). In this reported study, the sulfur content (800 ppm SO2) in the sulfur-resistance test was very high and the catalyst still maintained 80% SCR activity, which demonstrated the strong anti-poisoning capability of the catalyst [100]. Fe doping is also considered to be one of the most important methods for improving the sulfur tolerance of V-based catalysts. Gao et al. [102] prepared a V2O5-WO3-Fe2O3/TiO2 microsphere catalyst using an impregnation method that exhibited high sulfur tolerance. In a flue gas containing SO2, the NO conversion of the V2O5-WO3-Fe2O3/TiO2 microsphere catalyst maintained a conversion rate above 70% at a GHSV of 30,000 h−1 [102]. In addition, the sulfur resistance of the V2O5/TiO2 catalysts was found to be improved by introducing Cu [103] or Ba [108]. Although the low temperature SCR activity and sulfur resistance of modified V-based catalysts have been improved obviously, the development and application of V-based catalysts are still limited by biological toxicity of VOx. 3.1.3 Ce based DeNOx catalyst CeO2 is considered to be a catalyst that has good SCR activity at medium temperatures. During the reduction of Ce (IV) to Ce (III), oxygen is released and oxygen vacancies are formed in the catalyst. Oxygen vacancies make it easy for the catalyst to absorb molecular O2, which can convert Ce (III) to Ce (IV), thus completing the catalytic cycle. However, the catalysts with CeO2 as a single active component exhibit poor SCR activity at low temperatures (<200 °C), while the CeO2 catalysts exhibit high DeNOx performance in flue gases containing SO2 at 250–400 °C. However, Ce-based catalysts could not maintain their activity under long-term SO2 exposure in flue gas conditions. For example, Xu et al. [109] prepared Ce/TiO2 catalysts using an impregnation method and they found that the pathway for the transformation between Ce(IV) and Ce(III) was blocked in the presence of SO2, which resulted in the deactivation of the Ce-based catalysts. In addition, ammonium sulfate deposition on the Ce/TiO2 catalysts is also a problem. The anti-SO2 poisoning capability of Ce-based SCR catalyst can be improved by doping it with other transition metals. For example, Du et al. [110,111] prepared Ce-Cu-Ti catalysts using a co-precipitation method, and in the presence of SO2, sulfation of the Cu occurred prior to sulfation of Ce. In addition, the formation of CuSO4 prevented the sulfation of nearby Ce atoms. Since CuSO4 is considered to have some SCR activity [112], CuSO4-CeO2/TiO2-SiO2 was found to exhibit good SCR performance in a flue gas containing SO2 or H2O [112]. However, when SO2 and H2O were present in the flue gas, the reactions were seriously deactivated after 50 h of testing. Shi et al. [113] synthesized a Cu-Ce-S nanocrystalline catalyst using PS as a template. The NOx conversion of the Cu-Ce-S nanocrystalline catalyst was decreased by only 3% in flue gas containing SO2 at a GHSV of 40,000 h−1. However, under the same conditions, the conversion rate of the pure CeO2 catalyst was decreased by 64%. Through further characterization, it was found that the copper ion substituted for part of Ce4+ ion in the lattice of CeO2, and this site tended to bind with sulfate species thereby effectively preventing the poisoning of active sites (Ce4+). This is an important reason why the Cu-Ce-S nanocrystalline catalyst exhibited excellent resistance to sulfur poisoning [113]. In addition to Cu doping, Fe [114,115], Sm [116,117] and Sn [118,119] doping can also significantly enhance the resistance to SO2 of the Ce-based. If the reaction temperature is higher than 250 °C, the SCR reaction on the Fe-Ce/TiO2 catalyst prepared by Shu et al. was reported to follow the E–R mechanism [114], and the effect of SO2 on activity of the catalyst was relatively small (Fig. 8 ). However, when the reaction temperature was lower than 250 °C, the SCR reaction on this catalyst mainly followed L-H pathway, and the deposition of ammonium sulfate caused significant deactivation. Chang et al. [120] prepared a Ge-doped CeO2-WO3 catalyst using a co-precipitation method. The authors found that the activity and sulfur resistance results for this catalyst showed that Ge-doped catalyst exhibited improved SCR performance at low temperature, but also showed improved SO2 resistance (about 10%, at a GHSV of 50,000 h−1). In addition to using Ge doping to improve the anti-poisoning performance of the Ce-W system, Fe [121] and Cu doping can also improve the sulfur resistance of the Ce-based catalyst. For example, Fe was doped into the Ce-W system [121], and the conversion of NOx was nearly unchanged by a flue gas containing 200 ppm SO2 (Fig. 9 ). Another example is the Cu modified-CeO2-WO3 catalyst, which was found to exhibit good SO2 tolerance as reported by Shi et al. [122]. These authors also found that the addition of Cu helped to prevent the formation of (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 on the surface of Cu modified CeO2-WO3. Yu et al. [118] found that a Sn modified Ce-Ti catalyst exhibited good SO2 tolerance and SnO2 prevented the formation of Ti(SO4)2, Ce(SO4)2 and Ce2(SO4)3, but also significantly inhibited the deposition of (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 which might be the main reason for the good SO2-tolerance of Ce-Sn-Ti catalyst. Zhang et al. [123] then designed and prepared a Sn-doped Ce-Ti catalyst using a solvothermal method, which exhibited high resistance to sulfur poisoning. Co-doping of two elements in Ce-based DeNOx catalyst can also significantly improve the SO2 resistance of the catalyst. For example, Du et al. [124] loaded iron and copper sulfates into Ce-TiOx by co-precipitation, and the SCR activity of the resulting catalyst remained static, which suggested that the catalyst had a very strong resistance to sulfur. But the reaction temperature of the SO2 tolerance testing was 350 °C which was in the middle temperature range. 3.1.4 Fe-based DeNOx catalyst Iron-based catalysts have been extensively studied in NH3-SCR reactions at low temperature, because of their excellent redox performance, natural abundance, low-cost, non-toxicity and safety [125]. The study of Fe2O3 as the active component in NH3-SCR catalysts began early. In 1981, Kato et al. [126] reported a type of Fe2O3-TiO2 catalyst that exhibited good activity in the middle temperature range, which was prepared using metatitanic acid and ferric sulfate as precursors. Following this report, use of Fe2O3 as a single active component in SCR catalysts such as Fe2O3/CNTs [23] and Fe2O3 NRs [127] attracted the attention of many researchers. The SCR active temperature window of these catalysts was higher than 250 °C, which placed them in the middle temperature category. Although pure FeOx catalysts exhibit decent SO2 tolerance, it is worth mentioning that the sulfur tolerance of pure FeOx is better than pure MnOx. In recent years, many researchers have devoted time to further improving the SO2 resistance of iron-based catalysts and have achieved good results. Element doping in a Fe-based catalyst is one of the most common ways to improve the water resistance and sulfur resistance of the catalysts. For example, Shao et al. [128] investigated the effect of Co modification on the sulfur resistance of an α-Fe2O3 deNOx catalyst. Their results showed that the introduction of Co significantly improved the sulfur resistance of the catalyst, mainly because of the conversion of the Co3O4 into CoSO4 in the catalyst. The CoSO4 species subsequently proved to have catalytic activity for the NH3-SCR reaction. R.T. Yang's team from University of Michigan has reported Cr-doped Fe2O3-PILC catalysts, which prepared using pillared clay (PILC) as the support. It was found that a small amount of CrOx could further improve the NH3-SCR activity and anti-sulfur resistance capability. Further characterization showed that the presence of a bimodal pore structure might be an important reason why the catalyst exhibited high SO2 resistance [129]. In addition, Nd-P-WOx/FeOx [130], V2O5-Fe2O3/AC [131] and Fe-Cu-Ox/CNTs-TiO2 [132] catalysts were found to provide improved SCR activity in the low temperature range, as a result of their improved sulfur tolerance. 3.1.5 Zeolite DeNOx catalyst Although it has been reported that transition metals have been introduced into molecular sieves including ZSM-5 [133,134], SAPO-34 [135–137], SBA-15 [138–140], MCM-41 [141] and then used as low temperature DeNOx catalysts, it was found that the sulfur resistance of these catalysts was primarily unsatisfactory. And relatively few studies have been conducted using these catalysts. Ma et al. [142] prepared an excessively exchanged Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst by feeding sublimated ferric chloride into H-ZSM-5. The catalyst showed excellent SCR activity and this activity remained very stable over a wide temperature range. Further research showed that water in the reaction gas promoted the activity of the catalyst, but when SO2 was present as well, it decreased the SCR reaction rate at low temperature. However, it was found that the SO2 promoted the SCR reaction at high temperature, which indicated that the metal exchange zeolite catalyst prepared using this method had improved SO2 tolerance [142]. Therefore, this Fe-ZSM-5 zeolite catalyst has attracted significant attention for use in DeNOx applications. Subsequently, Carja G et al. [143] developed a new type of Fe-Ce-ZSM-5 catalyst that maintained an NO conversion rate of more than 75% over a wide temperature window (250–550 °C), and its catalytic activity was relatively stable in a flue gas that contained SO2 or H2O (GHSV = 332,000 h−1). Qi et al. [144] prepared Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts modified with precious metals (Pt, Rh and Pd) and found that the NOx conversion of the 0.1 wt% Pt/Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst decreased by less than 10% in flue gas containing SO2 at 250 °C. This result contrasted to that of the same catalyst in a sulfur-free flue gas (GHSV = 110,000 h−1), which indicated that the addition of precious metals to the catalyst significantly improved its SO2 tolerance. Zou et al. [145] found that a Mn-Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst prepared by chemical vapor deposition had excellent sulfur poisoning resistance once the synthesis method was optimized. The conversion rate of NOx for the optimized catalyst was higher than 80% in a sulfur-containing flue gas. The first application of zeolite-based catalysts was mainly for NOx control of automobile exhaust, and the reaction temperature of this process was in the medium and high temperature range for this reaction. In recent decades, many researchers have applied molecular sieves to the development of stationary source low temperature DeNOx catalysts, but there have been relatively few studies on the SO2 & H2O resistance of molecular sieve catalysts for low temperature NH3-SCR. In our opinion, molecular sieve-based SCR catalysts that maintain high activity in the presence of SO2 & H2O-containing flue gas should be developed, and their ability to resist SO2 & H2O poisoning should be considered as an important index for the evaluation of their performance in the design of new catalysts. 3.2 Appropriate support The term “appropriate support” mainly refers to a composite carrier catalyst or a catalyst with special carrier. In the area of industrial applications, supported catalysts are superior to non-supported oxide catalysts in many aspects, including high thermal stability and mechanical strength, low pressure loss, large specific surface area among others. Selection of suitable carriers is one of the important ways to improve the anti-poisoning capability of low temperature SCR catalysts [146]. Therefore, it is necessary to study the interaction between the carrier and the active component to best determine how to modify the catalyst support. This is because the activity of the SCR catalyst is affected by the adsorption of the toxic molecule SO2 on the surface of the catalytic support, and the degree of adsorption of the SO2 is related to the number of acidic sites on the support. Also, the adsorption of water can affect and change the acidity on the catalyst support. Hence, adjusting the surface acidity and redox performance of the support may be an effective means to enhance the low temperature SO2 tolerance of the SCR catalyst [147–149]. 3.2.1 Composite carriers In recent years, various researchers studied catalysts with composite carriers, and the support itself to determine their relative activity for catalytic reduction of NOx and/or sulfur poisoning tolerance. In order to improve the activity and anti-poisoning performance of the SCR catalyst at low temperature, the carrier should be doped or modified based on the needs of the SCR reaction [150,151]. Generally speaking, there are many types of composite carriers including a combination of two metals [152–155], a combination of metal and non-metal [150,156,157] and a combination of inert materials and metals [49,158–162]. Shen et al. [161] designed and synthesized Ti-containing pillared clays (Ti-PILCs) as a support for SCR catalysts. These Mn-CeOx/Ti-PILCs catalysts exhibited excellent anti-poisoning properties. The low temperature SCR reaction rate of these catalysts did not significantly decrease in the presence of a SO2 & H2O containing flue gas at 200 °C. Zang et al. [162] also prepared a V2O5/TiO2-PILC catalyst and found that the activity and anti-sulfur poisoning properties of their catalyst were better than a traditional V2O5/TiO2 catalyst. Subsequently, Lu et al. [159] prepared a 7% MnOx/TiO2-0.8% GE catalyst using an ultrasonic impregnation method. The NO conversion was maintained at over 75% in the presence of SO2 at a GHSV of 67,000 h−1. Subsequently, CeOx was introduced into the MnOx/TiO2-GE catalyst and it was found that the SO2-tolerance of the resulting CeOx-MnOx/TiO2-GE was somewhat enhanced [159]. We theorized that graphene could be introduced into titanium dioxide to form a sulfur-resistant composite carrier catalyst. In this case, the large specific surface area and excellent electronic transfer nature of graphene were exploited to improve the low temperature SCR performance of the catalyst [163]. Graphene is a relatively new form of carbon that exhibits a hydrophobicity that is higher than titanium dioxide. Therefore, the nano-composite titanium dioxide-GE appeared to play a role in improving the anti-poisoning performance of the resulting catalyst. In addition, the preparation of composite metal oxides as composite carriers for the low temperature DeNOx reaction have been widely reported, including the catalysts MnOx/Ce-Zr [154,155], MnOx/Ce-Ti [152], MnOx/Fe-Ti [164] and MnOx/Ti-W [153]. The activity of a MnOx/Ce-Zr catalyst prepared by Shen et al. [155] decreased slowly from 100% to 90% after feeding it a flue gas containing 100 ppm SO2 and 3% water vapor at 180 °C for 5 h (GHSV = 45,000 h−1). The activity of the catalyst nearly recovered to its original level after shutting off the 100 ppm SO2 and 3% water vapor. A MnOx/Ce-Ti catalyst was prepared by Xiong et al. [152] which maintained at 90% conversion rate over 10 h in the presence of an SO2 feed (WHSV = 60,000 mLg-1 h-1). The anti-poisoning performance of this MnOx/Ce-Ti catalyst was improved by 30% compared to a MnOx/CeO2 catalyst. Further characterization analysis showed that the Ce-Ti support was sulfated before the Mn, which reduced the inactivation of Mn active sites leading to high resistance to sulfur poisoning. Chen et al. [153] determined that a MnOx/Ti-W catalyst exhibited better sulfur poisoning resistance than a MnOx/Ti catalyst. They determined that the reason for the improvement of sulfur resistance of the catalyst may have been that the W in the catalyst inhibited the formation of sulfate species. It has also been reported that metal and non-metal composite carriers have been used to produce anti-poisoning resistant low temperature DeNOx catalysts such as Fe-Cu-Ox/CNTs-TiO2 [165], Mn-W-Ox/TiO2-SiO2 [10], CeO2/TiO2-SiO2 [150], etc. Kobayashi et al. [156] found that a V2O5/TiO2-SiO2-MoO3(TSM) catalyst exhibited excellent sulfur tolerance below 250 °C. The higher surface acidity and lower SO2 oxidation activity of the V2O5/TSM catalyst were the main reasons for its remarkable improvement in sulfur tolerance compared to a V2O5-MoO3/TiO2 catalyst. 3.2.2 Special carrier The structure of a catalyst support also has a significant influence on the SO2 resistance of a DeNOx catalyst at low temperature [166–169]. Loading MnOx onto 3D ordered macroporous carbon (3DMC) improved its SCR performance at low temperature, and the macroporous catalyst also appeared to possess a degree of anti-poisoning capacity [170]. The catalytic activity of MnOx/3DMC catalysts was maintained above 95% in a sulfur-containing flue gas at a GHSV of 36,000 h−1, which showed that the anti-poisoning performance of the MnOx/3DMC catalyst was much better than that of catalysts that contained only MnOx as a single active component. Lee et al. [171] also compared the sulfur-poisoning resistance of titanium nanotubes (TNTs) supported iron-manganese oxide catalysts with corresponding traditional titanium dioxide supported Fe-MnOx catalysts. These authors found that a SO2 tolerance test demonstrated that the Fe-MnOx/TNTs catalyst maintained about an 80% NO conversion rate in 100 ppm SO2 flue gas for 8 h (GHSV = 20,000 h−1), while the Fe-MnOx/TiO2 catalyst conversion rate under the same conditions was only about 50%. The authors speculated that the oxidized state of the Mn in Fe-MnOx/TNTs was not adversely affected by SO2 poisoning, which is one of the important reasons why the catalyst exhibited good sulfur tolerance. In addition, Shu et al. loaded V2O5-WO3-TiO2-Al2O3 [172] onto a wire mesh honeycomb (WMH) and loaded Ce-Fe-TiO2 onto a second WMH [173] and found that both these catalysts exhibited high sulfur tolerance. The authors attributed this high sulfur tolerance to the unique three-dimensional structure of these materials. The enhancement of specific carriers to control specific crystal surface exposure could improve SCR performance and anti-poisoning ability of the catalyst at low temperatures, which has become a hot research topic in the field of DeNOx technology [174–176]. Zhao et al. [177] developed a ZrCe/TiO2 catalyst for the NH3-SCR reaction and found that nano-sized TiO2 with the {001} crystal plane exposure exhibited the best SCR activity and high resistance to poisoning. The catalyst produced less NH4NO3, (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 in sulfur-containing flue gas as shown by further chemical characterization, which was an important reason for the excellent anti-poisoning capability of this material. Some experimental results showed that the carrier loaded with active components that were exposed on specific crystal surfaces exhibited better anti-poisoning performance than the same active components loaded on traditional supports. However, there was a decided lack of data to explain with the internal mechanism for the relationship between the exposed specific crystal surfaces of the support and the high anti-poisoning capability of the catalyst. In addition, researchers have also studied the application of metal oxides supported on different carriers for use in the low temperature NH3-SCR reaction and compared the effects of different carriers on the sulfur tolerance of the various catalysts [149,178,179]. Park et al. [180] used two different kinds of titanium dioxide (one was synthesized by CVC method and the other was commercial material) to support MnOx to form MnOx/TiO2 catalysts, and determined their relative sulfur resistance. The experimental results showed that the MnOx/TiO2-CVC catalysts exhibited better sulfur resistance, which was attributed to the presence of more active sites (amorphous Mn2O3) per unit mass in the MnOx/TiO2-CVC catalysts and less ammonium sulfate formed on the MnOx/TiO2-CVC catalyst was another reason for its high sulfur resistance. 3.3 Structure and morphology control 3.3.1 Control the pore structure of catalyst In the SCR reaction, the molecular diameters of the NO, NH3 and O2 are smaller than SO2 [181]. This fact can be brought to bear to exploit this molecular diameter difference in the SCR reaction to control the pore structure of the catalyst thereby minimizing the adsorption of SO2 molecules on the catalyst to control the poisoning of active sites or to reduce formation of ABS. This is an ideal method for obtaining high sulfur resistance in the SCR DeNOx catalyst at low temperature. Mesoporous silicas (MPS) are commonly used as a support in catalysis due to their regular pore structure and high surface area which facilitates good dispersion of the active phase. In the reported work in 2008, Huang et al. [182] synthesized various Fe-MnOx/MPS catalysts and found that these catalysts exhibited good resistance to SO2. Subsequently, Yu et al. [183] prepared a mesoporous MnO2-Fe2O3-CeO2-TiO2 catalyst using a sol-gel method and they realized NO conversion rates that finally stabilized at 80% in 300 ppm SO2 at 240 °C at a GHSV of 24,000 h−1. Compared to catalysts prepared by the traditional impregnation method, the mesoporous structure of MnO2-Fe2O3-CeO2-TiO2 catalyst was found to be one of the key factors for the high resistance to SO2 poisoning. Qiu et al. [184] and Wang et al. [185] have successfully prepared mesoporous Sn-doped Cr-MnOx (Fig. 10 ) and NiCo2O4 catalysts, which have also exhibited good sulfur resistance. Huang [182] and Yu et al. [183] concluded that the mesoporous structure of the catalysts was an important reason for their resistance to sulfur poisoning. However, the related mechanism and reasons for anti-poisoning capability of these mesoporous-structured catalysts are not very clear and will require further study. The deposition of ammonium bisulfate (ABS) on active catalyst sites is one of the main reasons for the deactivation of a large number of DeNOx catalysts [12]. Soh et al. [186] suggested that adjusting the pore structure of the catalyst could effectively control the degree of this deactivation, which was confirmed using a V2O5/Al2O3 catalyst. Further results [186] showed that the larger the specific surface area and pore size of the catalyst, the stronger its anti-SO2 poisoning capability, which could be explained by the Thomson's capillary condensation theory. This theory claims that the larger the pore size, the higher the vapor pressure, so the more difficult it is for aggregation of NH4HSO4 on the catalyst. Recently, Dong's team from Nanjing University found that the deposition and decomposition temperatures of ABS were very different for a mesoporous SBA-15 that had different average pore sizes [187]. Further study showed that the larger average pore size of the SBA-15, the faster the decomposition rate of ABS on SBA-15 (Fig. 11 ). Finally, using Fe2O3/SBA-15 as a model catalyst, the sulfur poisoning resistance of this catalyst was understood. The study showed that larger the pore sized Fe2O3/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited excellent sulfur poisoning resistance [187] (Fig. 12 ). In addition, Cai et al. [188] controllably prepared a series of Ce0.75Zr0.2M0.05O2-δ (M = Fe, Cu, Mn, Co) catalysts with a three-dimensional macroporous structure. Their results showed that the Ce-Zr-FeOx catalyst with a 3D macroporous structure exhibited high resistance to sulfur poisoning. However, they concluded that the strong interaction of Fe with the Ce-ZrOx solid solution, rather than the macroporous structure, was an important reason for the high sulfur resistance of the catalyst. 3.3.2 Control of morphology of the catalyst Nano-scale catalysts have special crystal structures and surface properties that result from their large specific surface area, high surface energy, etc., which makes them a hot topic in the field of environmental catalysis [16,175,189–192]. In the early stage, researchers found that the catalytic performance of nano-materials was closely related to characteristics of their morphology. The chemical and physical properties of nano-metal oxides with different morphologies differed greatly due to the various quantum size effects and macro-quantum tunneling effects. Later, it was found that the morphology of nano-materials could also affect the anti-poisoning performance of catalysts composed of these materials [193–196]. However, the effect of morphology and internal factors on the possible improvement in the poisoning resistance of DeNOx catalysts at low temperature requires further study. Zhang’s group from Shanghai University has conducted much work to improve the activity and SO2 tolerance of low temperature SCR catalysts by controlling their morphology. As a result, they have developed a series of low temperature DeNOx catalysts with strong sulfur and water tolerance [177,197–199]. These authors successfully synthesized Mn-Co nanocage catalysts derived from MOF nanocubes [199] and found that the catalytic activity of these catalysts did not decrease in a SO2-containing flue gas (Fig. 13 ). These authors suggested that the strong sulfur resistance of the catalyst was associated with the hierarchical pore structure, abundant active sites and the strong interaction between MnOx and CoOx in the nanocage catalyst. They also developed a series of hierarchical transition-metal vanadate nanosheets catalysts, which showed excellent resistance to sulfur poisoning [198]. In addition, Li et al. [193] prepared MnO2 with various morphologies (nanorods, nanosheets and nanospheres) using a redox hydrothermal method. These authors found that nanosphere-structured γ-MnO2 had good SCR activity at low temperature, but also had good tolerance to SO2. They continued to develop the MnFeOx nanorod catalyst for the SCR reaction at low temperature and the activity of the catalyst was maintained above over 85% in the presence of 200 ppm SO2 under a GHSV of 28,000 h−1 [200]. In recent years, morphological control of a structure to optimize and expose highly active facets in a catalyst support or active components of the catalyst has attracted great interest. This approach has been considered to be an effective strategy for improving the catalytic activity or the resistance to SO2 in these materials [174,201,202]. For example, Shi’s group from Xi'an Jiaotong University found that the SCR activity of the α-Mn2O3 single crystal with a truncated octahedron structure was superior to that of the α-Mn2O3 single crystal with a simple octahedral structure. This result was attributed to the exposure of a small fraction of the {001} facets in the truncated octahedron sample (Fig. 14 ). The authors also explained the reasons for the improvement in the SCR performance of the catalyst using density functional theory (DFT) calculations that showed that charge redistribution was responsible for the generation of new active sites on the {001} facets [201]. This work provides new insights into the most fundamental factors that dominate crystal-facet-dependent reactivity. Professor Fan’s team found that the MnOx/TiO2(NS) catalyst with preferentially exposed {001} facet exhibited higher activity for low temperature than the MnOx/TiO2(NP) catalyst with preferentially exposed {101} facets. In addition, they also found that the MnOx/TiO2 (NS) catalyst had better resistance to SO2 compared to the MnOx/TiO2 (NP) catalyst. Further investigations showed that the SO2 oxidation capability of the MnOx/TiO2 (NS) catalyst was not a critical factor in its high tolerance to SO2. They also found that the amount of Mn sulfate on the surface of the MnOx/TiO2 (NS) was lower and the formed Mn sulfate was easier to decompose in comparison to that on the MnOx/TiO2 (NP). This result translates into higher SO2 resistance in the MnOx/TiO2 (NS) catalyst [174]. Mou et al. [127] found that rod-shaped γ-Fe2O3 exposed with reactive {110} and {100} facets exhibited high SCR performance and this Fe-based catalyst with exposed specific crystal surfaces exhibited good resistance to sulfur poisoning. These investigations promoted crucial reconsideration the role of catalyst crystal facets in mediating SO2 poisoning as well as the intrinsic anti-poisoning mechanism. Unfortunately, investigations such as these of the various aspects of low temperature DeNOx catalysts have been greatly neglected, so much work remains to be done. 3.3.3 Control of special structures of the catalyst The special spatial structure of a catalyst is also an important aspect that can affect the sulfur resistance of a low temperature SCR catalyst. It has been reported that the eggshell structure, core-shell structure and special cage or pore structure can effectively block the interaction between toxic SO2 molecule and the active sites. These special structures can produce screening effects or mass transfer restrictions, which might significantly improve the anti-SO2 poisoning performance of catalysts [14,203–206]. In the early stage research, Richter et al. prepared a shell-type MnOx/NaY catalyst using a special precipitation technology. The low temperature activity and H2O-tolerance of this catalyst were found to be outstanding [207]. Regrettably, these researchers did not exhaustively investigate the sulfur resistance of the catalyst. Inspired by these reported results, many other researchers have developed a large number of core-shell structure catalysts for use in low temperature DeNOx, including Fe2O3@MnOx@CNTs [208], MnOx@CeO2 [203], meso-TiO2@MnOx-CeOx/CNTs [209], MoFe/Beta@CeO2 [210], CeO2@CeO-P [211] and so on. These catalysts have all exhibited very strong SO2-tolerance. As early as 2013, Zhang’s group prepared the core-shell structured catalyst by coating the mesoporous TiO2 layers on MnOx-CeOx/CNTs [209]. This catalyst had strong resistance to SO2, which resulted in a sustained 95% NO conversion in a flue gas containing 200 ppm SO2 (Fig. 15 ). The authors concluded that the strong interaction between MnOx, CeOx and TiO2 and the meso-TiO2 shell played a key role in preventing accumulated ammonium sulfate from occupying active sites and inhibiting the formation of manganese sulfate. Subsequently, Zhang’s group developed a multi-shell Fe2O3@MnOx@CNTs catalyst [208], which also exhibited excellent SO2-tolerance. Various characterization methods including TG and TPD confirmed that the main cause of the poisoning of the Mn@CNTs catalyst was the sulfation of the Mn species. However, Fe2O3 shell in the multi-shell Fe2O3@MnOx@CNTs catalyst appeared to inhibit the formation of sulfate compounds, which was also the key to its strong resistance to the sulfur poisoning of the catalyst at low temperature [208]. Yao et al. [211] developed a CeO2@Ce-O-P catalyst (multi-core@shell) and its SCR reaction activity was maintained at 75% for 20 h in a flue gas containing 100 ppm SO2 at 250 °C (GHSV = 40,000 h−1). It was found that the Ce-O-P layer provided acidic sites, but also avoided the formation of sulfate compounds through excessive adsorption of SO2, which played a key role in the SO2 resistance of the catalyst. Chi et al. [212] prepared a CeO2@Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst using layer-by-layer self-assembly method. The catalyst maintained a 80% NOx conversion rate in a sulfur-containing flue gas (GHSV = 20,000 h−1). However, the catalyst required a reaction temperature of 300 °C (medium temperature region). In addition, many core-shell DeNOx catalysts have been developed by other workers. All of these catalysts exhibited some degree of SO2 tolerance, and included Fe2O3@SiTi [213], CeO2@TiO2 [214], Fe2O3@CuOx [215], CuO@Cu-MOFs [216] and MnO2@NiCo2O4 [217]. 3.4 Control of catalyst preparation process As is well known, the process used to prepare the DeNOx catalysts can have a very important effect on their SCR activity and SO2 resistance. In general, the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst can be affected or adjusted by changing the preparation method, thereby determining the activity and SO2 resistance of catalysts. Therefore, in order to solve the problem of sulfur resistance in low temperature DeNOx catalyst, the preparation process could also be adjusted to improve the sulfur resistance of the catalyst by controlling the related characteristics of the catalyst. Much work has been done in this area. For example, Tang et al. [218] prepared a series of amorphous MnOx catalysts using three different methods (solid state reaction, co-precipitation and fluid phase change). Their results showed that the catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method had better anti- poisoning properties than the catalyst prepared by other two methods. Subsequently, Liu et al. [219] prepared Mn-Ce composite oxide catalysts by two different methods (surfactant-template and conventional co-precipitation method). After using the catalysts in SCR tests, it was found that the Mn-Ce composite oxide catalysts prepared using a surfactant-template method had better SO2 tolerance than a corresponding material prepared using a co-precipitation. Yao et al. [220] prepared a Ce-O-P catalyst using three different methods (sol-gel, hydrothermal and co-precipitation method). It was found that the catalyst prepared using the sol-gel method had the better SO2 tolerance than the other catalysts. The activity of the catalyst did not decrease significantly after 10 h of reaction, and the NOx conversion still exceeded 50% after 18 h in a SO2-containing flue gas (Fig. 16 ). The authors believed that the high SO2 resistance of the catalysts that had been prepared by sol-gel method was due to their abundant reactive oxygen species, which trapped the SO2. Solvothermal methods are often used to synthesize DeNOx catalysts [123,221], such as the pyridine-thermal, ethanol-thermal methods and so on. Zhang's group prepared MnCe/CNTs catalysts using three different methods (pyridine thermal method, impregnation method and mechanical mixing method). Of these, the catalysts prepared using the pyridine thermal method exhibited the best SO2-tolerance. In recent years, there have been many reports on the various methods for preparing low temperature SCR catalysts that have different SCR performance and SO2-tolerance [204,222]. In addition, various solvents or precursors can also affect the SO2 resistance of the catalyst. For example, Yao et al. [223] prepared Mn/CeO2 catalysts by impregnation of the support with different solvents (deionized water, anhydrous ethanol, acetic acid and oxalic acid). Of the catalysts prepared, the Mn/CeO2 catalysts (oxalic acid) exhibited the best resistance to SO2 & H2O. In another example, Chen et al. and Wu et al. used layered bimetallic hydroxides as precursors to prepare Mn-Fe-Al composite oxides [224] and Co-Mn-Al composite oxides [225]. The composite metal oxide catalysts derived from these particular precursors presented excellent resistance to SO2 poisoning. 3.5 Other methods used to improve the anti-poisoning performance of catalysts In order to solve the problem of sulfur poisoning of low temperature DeNOx catalyst, in addition to the modification of the active components, and selection of suitable supports and the control of catalyst preparation process, the sulfur resistance of catalyst could also be improved by other treatments processes, such as a pre-sulfurization process, changing the reaction conditions of the SCR flue gas and using coating materials, etc [14,226,227]. As early as 2005, Li Junhua's group from Tsinghua University prepared nano-sized Co3O4 catalysts under mild conditions. A nano-sized Co3O4 catalyst that had been thermally pre-treated under SO2 (pre-sulfurization: 500 ppm SO2, 300 °C, 48 h, GHSV = 25,000 h−1) exhibited sustained activity in the presence of a high sulfur flue gas. It was found that the pre-sulfated Co3O4 catalyst formed bulk sulfate over the catalyst surface without any adverse effect on its SCR activity [228]. Subsequently, a MnOx-CeO2 catalyst containing Sn as an additive was prepared using an ultrasound-assisted co-precipitation method. The sulfur resistance of the Sn modified MnOx-CeO2 catalyst was very high after pre-sulfurization (250 ppm SO2, 300 °C, 15 h, GHSV = 35,000 h−1) [26]. The reason for the strong sulfur tolerance of the catalyst at low temperature was that the pre-sulfurization of the catalyst system apparently produced Ce(III) sulfate, which significantly increased the acidity of the Lewis acid site, thus promoting the SCR reaction at low temperature (Fig. 17 ). Qiu et al. [229] also found that the sulfated Mn-Co-Ce/TiO2/SiO2 exhibited good low temperature catalytic activity and stronger resistance to sulfur poisoning in the presence of 50 ppm SO2. It is well known that NH4HSO4 deposition on the catalyst is the main cause of sulfur poisoning in the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst at low temperature. Recently, Wang et al. [230] found that the decomposition of NH4HSO4 could be increased by adding a select proportion of NO2 to the reaction flue gas for the DeNOx reaction over the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, because the ammonia ion of NH4HSO4 will be rapidly consumed by the NO2/NO mixture. This study also revealed that it was promising to stably and efficiently catalytically reduce NOx from SO2-contained flue gas by properly adjusting the NO2/NO ratio (Fig. 18 ). Zhang et al. [74] studied the effect of different sulfated temperatures on the activity of CeO2 catalysts. They found that the higher the sulfated temperature, the lower the activity of CeO2 catalysts after sulfation. Yang et al. [231] compared the sulfur poisoning resistance of a Mn-La-Ce-Ni-Ox composite catalyst with that of Mn-La-Ce-Ni-Ox catalyst coated on a functionalized membrane. It was found that the functional membrane catalyst coated with Mn-La-Ce-Ni-Ox composite exhibited better anti-poisoning performance. To date, researchers have conducted extensive research on low temperature DeNOx catalysts and increasing attention has been focused on improving the sulfur resistance of these catalysts. This part of this review summarizes the research status and strategies for improving the sulfur resistance of low temperature SCR catalysts, and the strategies for improving the sulfur resistance of high and low temperature DeNOx catalysts can be summarized as follows: (1) modification of active components to protect the main active sites from poisoning and inhibit the deposition of ammonium sulfate; (2) selection of appropriate carriers; carriers have an anti-poisoning effect, which has a greater impact on the overall catalyst resistance; (3) improvement of the sulfur tolerance of low temperature SCR catalysts by controlling structure (precise control of pore channels) and morphology; (4) controlled preparation methods and conditions; the preparation method can affect the crystallinity of the catalyst, the dispersion of the active components and the adsorption capacity for SO2, all of which can affect the sulfur resistance of the catalyst. 4 Strategies to reduce H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts In order to design low temperature catalysts with high resistance to water vapor, researchers have proposed many ideas, including: (1) using hydrophobic material as catalyst carrier or introducing hydrophobic material into catalyst; (2) controlling the pore structure of the catalyst; (3) reducing the adsorption of H2O onto the active center of catalyst by element doping; (4) controlling the specific morphology and structure of catalyst. Xiao et al. [232] successfully developed MnOx-CeO2/Graphene catalysts that exhibited excellent H2O durability at 180 °C with 10% H2O in the feed gas due to the introducing hydrophobic graphene. They also compared the water resistance of MnOx-CeO2 and MnOx-CeO2/graphene catalysts, and found that the MnOx-CeO2/Graphene catalysts offered little resistance to NOx conversion in water-containing flue gas. At the same time they found that the MnOx-CeO2 composite oxides exhibited an evident decrease in NO conversion [232] (Fig. 19 ). Therefore, these results suggested that the introduction of hydrophobic graphene in the catalyst is an important way to improve the H2O tolerance of the catalysts at low temperature. Li et al. [233] prepared activated carbon from sargassum and then loaded CrO3 onto the seaweed-based activated carbon (SAC) for use as a catalyst in the low temperature SCR reaction for the first time. It was reported that the CrO3/SAC catalyst for catalytic reduction of NOx could be maintained at more than 80% at low temperature in a flue gas containing water vapor at a GHSV of 15,000 h−1. However, the essential reason for strong H2O-tolerant performance of this catalyst was not thoroughly analyzed in this reported work. It is apparent that the use of hydrophobic materials as catalyst supports or the introduction of hydrophobic materials into the catalyst is an important method for improving the water resistance of low temperature DeNOx catalysts. However, there are obvious differences in the water resistance of the catalysts after introducing hydrophobic materials (two examples mentioned above). At present, there has been no quantitative study on the relationship between the hydrophobicity of materials and the water resistance of low temperature SCR catalysts. In other words, what is the relationship between the hydrophobicity level of the catalysts and their water resistance during SCR reaction at low temperature? Secondly, the essential reason why the hydrophobic catalysts have a strong resistance to water is a question that requires extensive study. Last but not least, the micro-mechanism of the behavior of nano-hydrophobic materials to water poisoning needs to be studied further. Only by exploring these problems in depth can we design and prepare low temperature SCR catalysts with strong water resistance. Controlling the pore structure of the catalysts is another important means for improving the water resistance of low temperature SCR catalysts [234–236]. Qiu et al. [234] reported that a 3-D mesoporous MnCo2O4 catalyst had high water resistance at low temperature. The NO conversion of these catalysts first decreased to 92% and then was maintained at 96% in a water-containing flue gas at 200 °C (GHSV = 32,000 h−1). The activity of the catalyst was restored to its initial level after the water vapor was removed from the flue gas. The authors also postulated that the large specific surface area of mesoporous materials increased the availability of active sites on the catalyst, thus delaying its deactivation by adsorbed water. NH3-TPD experimental results showed that a 3D mesoporous MnCo2O4 catalyst had more acidic surface sites, which produced preferential adsorption of large amounts of NH3 rather than H2O on the catalyst surface. This was also considered to be an important reason for the high water resistance of the catalyst [234]. Later, Yu et al. [235] reported that the large pore Mn-Ti-Ox catalyst was able to process higher NH3-SCR activity in the presence of H2O (Fig. 20 ). These authors claimed that the smaller pore size of the catalyst could made it easier for water to condense since water vapor tends to liquefy in small pores, while a larger pore size prevents the catalyst from condensing water. Moreover, the inert SiO2 modification was not adverse to the original low temperature SCR performance of the catalyst. It was found that the pore size of the catalyst was directly correlated to its water resistance at low temperature and the water that condensed in the pores of the catalyst decreased its activity [235]. The relationship between water tolerance at different temperature, pore size, and capillarity effects is shown in Fig. 21 . It was concluded that these data provided an important means for improving the water resistance of the SCR catalysts at high and low temperatures. However they also showed that there is a high correlation between the pore size of DeNOx catalysts and their water resistance at low temperatures. These results can be used as a guide in the design and preparation of low temperature DeNOx catalysts with good resistance to water poisoning. Elemental doping is also one of the most important means for improving the water resistance of low temperature DeNOx catalysts [49,81,237,238]. For example, Shen et al. [81] found that the water resistance of Fe-doped Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalysts could be improved by doping with Fe. Yang et al. [131] added V2O5 to FeOx/AC catalysts and found that the NOx conversion of the V2O5-FeOx/AC catalyst deceased more slowly in the presence of water vapor, which was an indication of the improved water resistance of this catalyst (Fig. 22 ). Yan et al. [237] prepared a Nb-modified a SnO2-CeO2 catalyst using a co-precipitation method. The SCR activity of this catalyst was greatly improved in the temperature window of 120–210 °C, and the long-term water resistance of the catalyst was also improved. Nb doping weakened the competitive adsorption of water on the surface of the catalyst during the SCR reaction, which improved the catalyst’s resistance to H2O [237]. Gao et al. [239] prepared a Ce-Cu-Ti-Ox catalyst using a co-precipitation method, which exhibited good water resistance at low temperature. They also found that the presence of water vapor at low temperatures resulted in a reduction in NO conversion of the catalyst and that water vapor enhanced the DeNOx capacity of the catalyst when the flue gas temperature was higher than 300 °C [239]. Control of the specific morphology and structure of the catalyst is another important means for improving the water resistance of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst. For example, Fan et al. [240] compared the water resistance of Fe-Mn oxide nanoneedles with that of Fe-Mn oxide nanoparticles at low temperature. The activity of Fe-Mn oxide nanoneedles catalyst was maintained at more than 90% in a water-containing flue gas at low temperature, while the NOx conversion of Fe-Mn oxide nanoparticles catalyst decreased significantly. Professor Smirniotis’s team from University of Cincinnati developed a manganese-confined titania nanotube catalyst with strong water vapor tolerance (Fig. 23 ), which was prepared by using an alkaline hydrothermal synthesis technique [241]. They also found that the existence of the highly active, redox potential pairs Mn4+ and Mn3+ preferentially located in the tubular framework and these may have been the key factor in the strong water vapor tolerance of the catalyst. Du et al. [242] prepared a Fe-ZSM-5@silicalite-1 catalyst using a two steps hydrothermal method and the water resistance of the product at low temperature was significantly improved. These authors suggested that the core-shell structure and hydrophobic silicalite-1 shell were the key factors involved in the strong water resistance of the catalyst. Bai et al. [243] obtained a CoOx@porous carbon catalyst with core-shell structure by pyrolysis and oxidation of ZIF-67 nanomaterials and the SCR activity of CoOx@porous carbon catalyst was nearly constant in a water-containing flue gas at 175 °C. This result indicated that this catalyst had excellent H2O-tolerant performance. Unfortunately, the main reason why this catalyst had excellent water resistance was not thoroughly determined in this reported work. However, it is believed that porous carbon with core-shell structure and surface hydrophobicity may be the important reason for its excellent H2O-tolerant performance. In addition, Ce-Mo-Ox hollow microspheres [244], MnOx/ZrO2-CeO2 [245] and MnOx-CoOy/H2Ti3O7 [246] catalysts have all exhibited good water resistance in water-containing flue gas at low temperature. These catalysts were developed by researchers in China and abroad. However, more attention should be placed to the anti-poisoning mechanism of the catalysts that exhibit a strong resistance to poisoning. Only by mastering these universal poison-resistant mechanisms can low temperature DeNOx catalysts with excellent H2O-tolerant ability be designed and prepared. In recent years, researchers in the development of low temperature catalysts with high SO2 & H2O tolerance have made significant advancements.
