The studies over the past five years of low temperature DeNOx catalysts with excellent SO2 & H2O-tolerant ability are summarized in Table 1 . 5 Application of theoretical calculations in the development of SO2 & H2O resistant SCR catalysts Catalytic reactions are rapid processes, so they require more than experimental and related characterizations to fully understand the role of catalysts and grasp the entire catalytic process at the micro-scale. Fortunately, the rapid development of quantum computational chemistry now provides a new method for developing new catalysts. Compared to experiments, quantum chemical calculations offer the following advantages: (1) safety and low cost; (2) rapid reactions or changes can be easily studied; (3) accuracy, high efficiency and good repeatability; (4) a deep grasp of complex and microcosmic problems. In the field of SCR DeNOx, the application of quantum chemical theoretical calculations has focused on simulating the reaction pathway of the SCR reaction and the adsorption process of the reactant molecules on the catalyst surface in recent years [247,248]. For example, using theoretical calculations Fang et al. [43] confirmed that NH3 adsorption onto the MnOx surface was the first step in SCR reaction on this catalyst, which marked the rate determining step in the DeNOx process. The conclusions from the quantitative calculations were easily corroborated by experimental results so that the modeling process served as a guide in the design and optimization of the catalyst. However, there have been few reports in the literature detailing the use of quantitative calculations in the fabrication of low temperature DeNOx catalysts for improving SO2 & H2O tolerance. Theoretical calculations can be used to select anti-poisoning elements for use in low temperature DeNOx catalysts. For example, early proposals were advanced by Ha et al. [105] to address the sulfur poisoning problem of V-based DeNOx catalyst using theoretical calculations. Many studies have shown that deactivation of sulfur poisoning of SCR catalysts can be attributed to the sulfation of the metal atoms and the deposition of ammonium sulfate. The main reason for the deactivation of low temperature DeNOx catalysts containing V2O5 as the main active component is the large amount of ammonium bisulfate deposited on the surface of the catalyst. This poisoning process can be simplified as follows (Fig. 24 ): ammonium bisulfate adsorbs on the surface of the catalyst’s V transition metal, which replaces with an arbitrary atom M. In this adsorption model, the MO bond, which is normally far stronger than the adjacent HO bond (see Fig. 24), plays an important role in the SO2 poisoning. As the MO becomes weaker, more ammonium bisulfate salt is desorbed from the surface of the catalyst, producing the lowest amount of ammonium bisulfate salt deposits on the catalyst surface. Using this theory, quantitative calculations for a variety of metal dopants (Se, Sb, Cu, S, B, Bi, Pb, P, etc.) were conducted using this particular model. The results favored the transition metal Sb as the optimum dopant, so that a Sb-V2O5/TiO2 catalyst was prepared and tested for its SO2 & H2O resistance. After H2O and SO2 were introduced into reaction gas, the Sb-doped catalyst produced a high NO conversion rate at a reaction temperature of 240 °C. This is a classic example of the development of a low temperature DeNOx catalyst with strong resistance to SO2 & H2O by using theoretical calculations to design the catalyst and experimental results to confirm the model. Theoretical calculations can also simulate the adsorption behavior of reaction molecules and poisonous molecules on the catalyst surface to establish a quantitative structure-activity relationship. For example, Du et al. [111] studied the effect of water vapor on Ce-Cu-Ti complex oxide SCR catalysts, which was investigated using a combination of the designed experiments and theoretical calculations. The results of these studies indicated that water vapor had a dual effect. That is, the NO conversion rate of the Ce-Cu-Ti catalyst decreased in the presence of H2O at low temperature (below 300 °C), while the SCR activity of Ce-Cu-Ti catalysts increased in the presence of H2O at relatively high temperature (above 300 °C). By calculating the adsorption energies of H2O and NH3 molecules on the catalyst at different specific sites (Fig. 25 ), it was found that the competitive adsorption of H2O with NH3 resulted in a decrease of NH3 adsorption capacity, which led to a decrease of the SCR performance of the catalyst. On the other hand, the presence of H2O can inhibit the oxidation rate of NH3 by the catalysts at relatively high temperature, which helps to increase the amount of NH3 that can act as a reducing agent. This enhanced the SCR activity of the catalyst. A schematic diagram of the reaction mechanism of water vapor on a Ce-Cu-Ti composite oxide DeNOx catalyst is shown in the following figure (Fig. 26 ). Zhang et al. [249] studied the adsorption behavior of six reaction gases on a Mn-MOF-74 metal-organic framework catalytic system using DFT analysis. The co-adsorption experiments of NH3 and H2O, NH3 and SO2 showed that there was competitive adsorption of these molecules on the Mn metal sites (Fig. 27 ). It was also found that it was easier for SO2 to replace NH3 than H2O, which explained the difference between the H2O poisoning effects and the SO2 poisoning effects. In addition, theoretical calculations can also help to explain the reaction process of various molecules on the surface of the catalysts. Previous studies by our group used a “one-pot” hydrothermal method to introduce Ce into a SAPO-34 framework to obtain a heteroatomic CeAPSO-34 zeolite [250]. At the same time, we developed a MnOx-CeOx/CeAPSO-34 catalyst using an ethanol dispersion method, which was able to maintain a 65% conversion rate in a flue gas containing sulfur dioxide and water vapor at low temperature at a GHSV of 40,000 h−1. The theoretical results implied that the high anti-poisoning effects of the catalyst were attributed to the [–Ce–O–Ce–] units, which suggested that the Ce site next to a neighboring Ce site in the framework was beneficial to the reaction with SO2. Theoretical calculations can also help in the analysis and understanding of the changes in electronic dispersion and structures of the catalyst resulting from elemental doping, and help to explain the relationship between these changes and the anti-poisoning performance of the catalyst. Wei et al. [251] studied the effects of doped atoms on the electronic dispersion and crystal structure of MnO2 {100} using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Using the calculations and analysis of SO2 adsorption energy at specific sites as well as the related PDOS, the authors found that Cr is an important doping element for improving the sulfur resistance of Mn-based catalysts. It was found that the Cr-dopped MnO2 catalyst can convert SO2 to Brønsted acid sites, which can participate in completing the NH3-SCR reaction cycle through an L-H pathway. This was how Cr doping of the MnO2 catalyst improved its SO2 tolerance. Lu et al. [252] studied the adsorption process of SO2 on the surface of a CeOx catalyst and the formation of sulfation using DFT calculations. These authors found that the formation of sulfates and sulfites was accompanied by the transport of surface electrons from CeOx to the LUMO (2b1) of the SO2, which suggested that the weakening of intramolecular SO bonds activates the dissociation of SO2. In addition, they also claimed that a surface monodentate sulfate species was formed by introducing an oxygen vacancy adjacent to the sulfite species, which was also confirmed by SO2 adsorption experiments. In our opinion, this study provides a deeper understanding of how SO2 adsorbs on CeOx surface to form a sulfate species. It shows the significance of theoretical calculations in providing a guide for the design and preparation of catalysts with good anti-sulfur poisoning capabilities. Yang et al. [253] studied the SO2 poisoning effect of different copper species on a Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst using DFT calculations. The results of this study suggested that isolated bivalent copper was not conducive to SO2 adsorption, while SO2 is more likely to be adsorbed on the Cu+ and Cu+/H+ sites of the catalysts. The formation of a CuSO4 complex is easier when Cu has a low oxidation state. They believed that the simultaneous existence of H2O and O2 accelerated the accumulation of copper sulfate at the isolated Cu2+ sites, thereby accelerating the deactivation of the catalyst. In conclusion, theoretical calculations have been used in some studies to improve the SCR performance of low temperature DeNOx catalysts or to explain the reasons why specific catalysts have anti-poisoning capabilities, such as Jin [78] and Wei et al. [251]. However, there have been only a few literature reports dealing with the application of the theoretical calculation method in the development of low temperature DeNOx catalysts with strong anti-poisoning properties. In our opinion, theoretical calculations is one of the most important methods that can be employed in the development of anti-poisoning SCR catalysts, and it will also be an important development trend in the field of environmental catalysis in the future. Our group is of the opinion that theoretical calculations and experimental exploration should be further combined to explore some of the more pressing current catalyst problems. For example (1) exploration of the formation and evolution of sulfur species in the low temperature SCR process; (2) improvement of specific indicators of a catalyst by calculating targeted design to reduce sulfur poisoning; (3) study of the micro-mechanisms of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts by means of combination of the quantitative calculation and in situ characterization. 6 Novel ideas for developing low temperature SCR catalysts with high resistance to poisoning In addition to the anti-poisoning strategies mentioned above for low temperature SCR catalyst, some researchers have found novel ways to develop SCR catalysts with strong resistance to poisoning. For example, Professor Tang’s team has prepared Fe-Mo layered structure catalyst with high poisoning resistance [254], whose self-protection mechanism inhibits the formation of ammonium bisulfate on the surface of the catalyst. This mechanism is presented in the layered structure of MoO3 that can facilitate the capture of NH4 + from ammonium bisulfate, which was verified by in situ characterization. Also, in situ characterization has suggested that the ammonium bisulfate decomposition was present when the Fe-Mo layered structure catalyst was used in the SCR process. This decomposition of ammonium bisulfate included three steps as concluded by Tang’s team [254]. These were: (1) spatial separation of the ammonium ion from HSO4 − by overcoming the strong electrostatic interactions in ammonium bisulfate; (2) reactive consumption of the spatial separated ammonium ion from HSO4-; (3) separation of the surface HSO4- from ammonium bisulfate that was oxidized by the catalyst and release of SO2. This work may provide a new strategy for the design and fabrication of low temperature NH3-SCR catalysts with very high and stable resistance to poisoning, which could be applied to various industrial boilers for controlling of NOx emissions. Li et al. [255] also provided a new idea for treating sulfur poisoning of the SCR catalyst at low temperature. They developed the RHO-type membrane, which could make the SO2 molecule separated from NOx containing flue gas, and this decreases the contact between the SO2 molecule and low temperature SCR catalyst below 250 °C, giving the monolithic catalyst possess excellent SCR activity. The whole process design is shown in Fig. 28 . Professor Dong’s team from Nanjing University developed a complex catalytic system (CC, Figs. 29 ) with excellent resistance to sulfur poisoning [256]. These authors found a new way where they designed three-in-one catalytic system and used MnOx as the DeSOx catalyst. The CC system included (1) MnOx as DeSOx catalyst; (2) gamma-Al2O3 as buffer layer; (3) Mn-Ce composite oxide as final low temperature NH3-SCR catalyst. This CC complex catalytic system exhibited excellent SCR activity at low temperature in a flue gas containing SO2 & H2O over a long time period. The key to the strong resistance to SO2 of this CC complex catalytic system was that the first part of MnOx acts as a desulfurizer and ensures the SCR activity of the third part. The last part of low temperature SCR catalyst provided a full role to the high performance of low temperature SCR without SO2 in flue gas. This work also provided a new approach for solving the problem of SO2 & H2O poisoning of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst. 7 Regeneration of low temperature SCR catalyst Generally speaking, low temperature SCR catalysts are used for flue gas DeNOx process for extended periods in the presence of SO2, which unavoidably leads to catalyst deactivation [120]. Hence, regeneration of these low temperature SCR deactivated catalysts is a necessary requirement of their use. This is very important for improving the economics of low temperature SCR technology in industrial applications. However, there have only been a few studies dealing with the regeneration of deactivated low temperature SCR catalysts. Recent regeneration studies of deactivated low temperature SCR catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . There are many regeneration methods for deactivated low temperature SCR catalysts, including water washing, water washing with ultrasonic vibration, thermal regeneration, thermal reduction regeneration, etc [27,77,78,90,120,182,218,257–259]. These regeneration methods provide different results due to different conditions and active components of deactivated catalysts [260]. The effectiveness of regeneration of these various methods (water washing, thermal regeneration, reductive regeneration, etc.) for recovering the catalytic activity of Mn-Ce/TiO2 was systematically compared by Sheng and co-workers [27]. They found that the SCR catalytic activity of a used Mn-Ce/TiO2 could be restored to the level of a fresh catalyst by water washing with ultrasonic vibration. This study indicated that the regeneration effectiveness of water washing with ultrasonic vibration was the best and the regeneration effectiveness of heating in air was the worst. Jin et al. [78] found that the SO2 poisoning effect on the Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst was directly related to the reaction temperature. They found that the higher the reaction temperature, the more rapidly the catalyst activity decreased and this type of deactivated catalyst could be recovered to its original activity after water-washing treatment. According to analysis and comprehensive summary of the related literatures, it was concluded that the SO2 poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts can be described in three periods (Fig. 30 ). Period A is where most of the low temperature SCR catalysts maintained very good SCR activity for a long time in the absence of SO2. However, these low temperature SCR catalysts generally exhibited a decline in SCR activity over time in sulfur-containing flue gas conditions, which is considered to be Period B. The formation of ammonium sulfate and metal sulfate during the SCR reaction produces various degrees of catalyst deactivation. There are also two stages in Period B for low temperature SCR catalysts. In the SO2 & H2O resistance test, we found that when SO2 & H2O were introduced into the flue gas, the activity of most catalysts showed a sharp decrease (stage I), and then the activity of the catalyst was maintained at a relatively stable level (stage II). But in stage II the activity of the catalyst still exhibited a slow downward trend. As time progressed, the low temperature SCR catalyst may be completely deactivated over time in the presence of SO2. A comprehensive study of the key causes and mechanisms of catalyst deactivation in these two stages needs to be conducted, especially where the activity of the catalysts decreases at different rates. Relevant model catalysts are needed to study these issues. Moreover, in order to evaluate the anti-poisoning levels of the catalyst at the basic scientific research level, we have classified the catalysts according to their initial activity as they entered the stage II (XII). If the XII is higher than 90%, this is considered to be an outstanding anti-poisoning property for the catalysts. If the XII is about 60–90%, this is considered to be an acceptable anti-poisoning property. In fact, the time over which the catalyst can maintain high activity under real flue gas conditions is also an important indicator of the anti-poisoning performance of the catalyst. The deactivated low temperature SCR catalyst should be regenerated in Period C. According to this condition, this author believes that breakthroughs are required in the following three aspects: First, both the toxicity-resistant time of the low temperature SCR catalyst and its initial activity of XII need to be increased; Second, better regeneration methods of deactivated catalyst need to be studied and developed; Third, a novel online or in situ catalyst regeneration system should be developed. Last but not least, we also need to study how a specific regeneration method can improve the activity of poisoning catalyst and to further explore the internal mechanisms of the specific method by in situ characterization [261,262]. 8 Conclusions and perspectives It is clear that low temperature NH3-SCR is an efficient technology for transforming NOx into N2, with a favorable economic value and broad application prospects, such as the flue gas DeNOx process in thermal power plants, waste incinerators, the cement industry and so on. However, the challenge of the poisoning of low temperature NH3-SCR catalysts by SO2 and H2O in the gas stream remains to be solved because the deactivation of the catalyst is a complicated process. The sulfur tolerance of catalysts is affected by many factors including, active components, supports, structures, morphologies, preparation methods, etc. Although low temperature SCR catalysts with good low temperature SCR activity and SO2 & H2O tolerance have been developed for use under laboratory conditions, even after much long-term research they are far from being ready for “prime time” in real industrial applications. This review has attempted to summarize the progress that has been made in the development of low temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx over the past decades by taking a visual approach that focuses on the problem of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts. The mechanism of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalyst, the strategy for improving SO2 & H2O catalyst resistance to poisoning, application of theoretical calculations in the development of SO2 & H2O resistant low temperature SCR catalysts were discussed. Moreover, novel ideas for developing low temperature SCR catalysts with high resistance to poisoning and the aspect of catalyst regeneration of low temperature SCR catalyst were also reviewed. Despite the progress made in this field, many issues remained must be resolved in order to develop improved low temperature SCR catalysts with strong anti-poisoning properties for use in industry. Moving forward, we consider that future efforts should focus on the following aspects: (1) Most of the present low temperature SCR catalysts developed to resist poisoning can be improved by metal modification, while most of the anti-poisoning tests of the developed catalysts appeared to exhibit a modest anti-poisoning effect of less than 100 h, and the activity of the catalysts appeared to decrease to a very low level for a longer time in the presence of SO2. Therefore, the design and development of low temperature SCR catalysts with long-term tolerance to poisoning is needed based on a top-level design. In addition, long-term sulfur resistance tests of the low temperature DeNOx catalyst should be conducted as a basic research process. Moreover, the effect of toxic molecules (SO2 and H2O) on the N2 selectivity of the catalysts should also be explored. (2) Based on the current study, we have provided a preliminary mechanism for the sulfur and water poisoning of low temperature DeNOx catalysts. However, the actual process and the most intrinsic cause of sulfur/water vapor poisoning have not been thoroughly studied, which should receive special attention. (3) The microscopic reaction mechanisms responsible for the SO2 and H2O poisoning process of each specific catalyst require further study. In our opinion, it is in situ characterization techniques such as FT-IR are not in and of themselves sufficient to ascertain the subtleties of the poisoning process of catalyst. To fully detail the inner workings and hidden mechanisms of the catalyst poisoning process, we believe that techniques such as in situ FTIR should be augmented with other analytical methods, such as synchrotron-radiation, steady-state isotope transient dynamics analysis, isotopic tracer techniques, highly sensitive real-time monitoring techniques (proton-transfer reaction-mass spectrometry) and theoretical calculations (simulate mass- and heat-transfer effects of the given catalyst and indicate the reaction behavior of specific catalytic systems). (4) Most reported studies have explored the causes of catalyst poisoning from the view point of the changes in the physicochemical properties of catalysts. In future studies, the mechanism of sulfur poisoning should be analyzed based on the reaction kinetics, which will provide a deeper understanding of the mechanisms of catalyst poisoning. (5) Most of the reaction paths and mechanisms of the low temperature SCR catalyst have been conducted in the absence of SO2 & H2O. There has been little research done on the mechanism, reaction paths and reaction energy barriers of the SCR reaction at low temperature in the presence SO2 & H2O. Consequently, we cannot adequately understand the poisoning of the catalyst and the reaction pathway under real conditions. (6) The characterization methods including electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) and X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) have been used to detect and determine the microstructures and coordination environment of the catalysts. Taking full advantage of these characterization technologies, the changes in the active sites on the surface of low temperature SCR catalysts in flue gas containing SO2 and H2O should be determined, and the effects of the catalyst microstructures and coordination environment on the reaction pathway of the low temperature SCR reaction should be investigated, which may help to clearly determine the changes in the catalysts in flue gases containing SO2 and H2O. (7) The deactivation rate of the catalyst is related to the fuel type, burner type, temperature of flue gas and catalyst design. The composition of the flue gas also varies from industry to industry. Therefore, specific anti-poisoning low temperature DeNOx catalyst should be developed that are tailored to meet the demands of each individual industry. (8) Currently, a large number of low temperature SCR catalysts with certain anti-poisoning properties have been developed, using different preparation conditions, evaluation parameters of activity and active composition, all of which have affected the anti-poisoning behavior of the catalysts. Therefore, it is necessary to establish a database of low temperature DeNOx, and catalysts use this to acquire uniformity data for industrial use. In particular, the parameters of sulfur and water resistance of low temperature DeNOx catalysts must be included, which can effectively avoid unnecessary duplication of work. (9) The currently developed low temperature SCR catalysts are mainly powders rather than monolithic solids. Since there is still a large difference between laboratory simulations and industrial pilot tests in terms of catalyst activity, researchers should pay closer attention to the application of low temperature SCR monolithic catalysts in pilot and industrial tests. In addition, the regeneration (especially in situ or novel regeneration) of anti-poisoning low temperature SCR catalysts deserves further investigation. (10) Elemental doping of low temperature SCR catalysts has helped to improve their poisoning resistance. Nevertheless, the question still remains as to why doping significantly improves the anti-poisoning performance of the catalyst and the poisoning resistance mechanism requires further exploration. (11) Another key issue is how to decrease the decomposition temperature and dew point temperature of ammonium bisulfate under reaction conditions, and to prevent the ABS from occupying active sites, and how to promote NH3 adsorption to improve the anti-poisoning performance of the SCR catalyst. (12) Other important issues that need to be clarified include establishing correlations between the spatial structure of the catalysts, dispersion of active components, exposure of specific crystal surfaces, the electronic structure, the ability to oxidize SO2 by low temperature SCR catalysts and the degree of sulfation of low temperature DeNOx catalysts. In other words, the key factors of low temperature SCR catalysts that determine their tolerance to SO2 require further exploration. We believe that this review will provide a great foundation and reference point for future design and development in developing low temperature SCR catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Low temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is an efficient and promising technology to transform NOx into N2 from flue gases, which has broad application prospects. However, the vulnerability of low temperature DeNOx catalysts to poisoning by SO2 and H2O restricts their industrial application. Therefore, it is vitally important to develop new low temperature DeNOx catalysts that resist poisoning. This paper reviews the mechanisms of SO2 & H2O poisoning of low temperature SCR catalysts, the strategies for improving the resistance of low temperature SCR catalysts to SO2 & H2O poisoning, application of theoretical calculations in the development of SO2 & H2O resistant low temperature SCR catalysts as well as novel ideas for developing poisoning resistant low temperature SCR catalysts. Moreover, the studies dealing with the regeneration of low temperature DeNOx catalysts are also included. Based on the problems detailed in this review, the challenges and the emphasis for future research in this area are also proposed. We believe that this review will provide an excellent foundation and good guidance for the future design and the development of improved SO2 & H2O-tolerant low temperature DeNOx catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Research progress, challenges and perspectives on the sulfur and water resistance of catalysts for low temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3
